page.title: 03THE TEES AND FLATTS WOODS
page.content: Once the Durham-Yorkshire boundary,the River Tees is in its middle tract. Salmon came up the river till 1930. Crayfish in the river show the water is pure. The river is fished for brown trout. Two years ago,creosote from a quarry poured down the river.Fish jumped from the water in agony and died.The river was flushed and restocked.Before the building of Cow Green Reservoir a huge roll flooded the river after rain in the hills.The woods by the river are the remnants of the Marwood Chase hunting forest.Lord Barnard (Raby Estates) owns some of Flatts Wood,and Durham County Council the rest.Raby have recently felled part of the woods and are replanting with oak and beech. Other areas replanted about 20 years ago are larch ,oak and beech.Deer, squirrels and other animals live in the woods.{
